results.headline: Suds, Southern Scenery and Fistfuls of Weaponry
results.summary_short: When Sissy Spacek speaks her clichéd lines in the mediocre screenplay of “Lake City,” her delivery lends them a resonance that is not in the written words.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lake City

results.headline: Canine TV Action Star Discovers That Life Is the Best Reality Show
results.summary_short: “Bolt” is at once a knowing, satirical sendup of the Hollywood fame-and-fantasy machinery and a sleek product of the Disney-Pixar industrial complex.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bolt

results.headline: Convulsions of a Family and an Abandoned Country
results.summary_short: “The Betrayal (Nerakhoon)” is quiet, contemplative and impressionistic, which makes the story it has to tell all the more powerful.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Betrayal

results.headline: Back in 1968, When a Tie Was No Tie
results.summary_short: Kevin Rafferty makes the case for remembrance and for the art of the story in his preposterously entertaining documentary “Harvard Beats Yale 29-29.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harvard Beats Yale 29-29

results.headline: Ah, Home for the Holidays and Extra Helpings of Family Dysfunction
results.summary_short: After two and a half hours in the thrilling, exhausting company of the characters in “A Christmas Tale,” the intimacy we feel with them is wired with surprise.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Christmas Tale

results.headline: The Common Wounds of a Neglected Marriage
results.summary_short: “Eden” is a picture so modest and minor-key that the emotional bruise it leaves may take days to develop.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eden

results.headline: Rotten Tomatoes
results.summary_short: “The Dukes” tastes like pasta sauce that has sat on the shelf long after the expiration date on the can.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dukes

results.headline: Ready for a Spring Thaw: Bickering, Controlling Old Folks With Frozen Souls
results.summary_short: A good scolding and a toke on a joint: that’s all it takes to turn the curmudgeonly old folks in “How About You” into goofy pussycats.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How About You (Movie)

results.headline: Even After the Books, Pottermania Rocks On
results.summary_short: The filmmaker Josh Koury has latched onto a great subject for “We Are Wizards,” his peek at some of the more engaged fans circulating in the Harry Potter world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are Wizards

results.headline: From Child Soldier to Hip-Hop Artist
results.summary_short: “War Child,” a documentary about the hip-hop artist Emmanuel Jal, is a bit ragged and repetitive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War Child

results.headline: The Evils of the Medical-Industrial Complex
results.summary_short: “The Beautiful Truth” is a documentary about contemporary health hazards and alternative treatments.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beautiful Truth

results.headline: Lonely Old Men and Drugged Young Virgins
results.summary_short: Not even the august presence of Maximilian Schell can dispel the odor of fusty smut that clings to “House of the Sleeping Beauties.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House of the Sleeping Beauties

results.headline: 007 Is Back, and He’s Brooding
results.summary_short: “Quantum of Solace” prompts the question: Is revenge the only possible motive for large-scale movie heroism these days?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quantum of Solace

results.headline: Orphan’s Lifeline Out of Hell Could Be a Game Show in Mumbai
results.summary_short: A gaudy, gorgeous rush of color, sound and motion, “Slumdog Millionaire” doesn’t travel through the lower depths, it giddily bounces from one horror to the next.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slumdog Millionaire

results.headline: Those Darn Kidults! The Menace of Eternal Youth
results.summary_short: Judd Apatow neither wrote nor directed “Role Models.” But he might as well have.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Role Models

results.headline: Straddling the Line Between Art and Smut
results.summary_short: “Otto; Or, Up With Dead People” is sexy and silly in just the right proportions, a cult item with a real heart.
results.display_title: Otto; or, Up with Dead People

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Otto; or, Up with Dead People

results.headline: Racial Oppression and Lesbian Longing
results.summary_short: “The World Unseen” is a trembling soap of racial oppression and lesbian longing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The World Unseen

results.headline: Shopping a Life Away
results.summary_short: “The Guitar” is an arty parable that suggests a New York bohemian variation on the odious “Bucket List.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Guitar

results.headline: Reunited for a Road Trip and an R&B Curtain Call
results.summary_short: “Soul Men” is a raucous, rambling comedy, offering some laughs, some groans and a feast for fans of the musical idioms it mocks and celebrates.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Soul Men

results.headline: Playing the Organs
results.summary_short: Darren Lynn Bousman, the director of several “Saw” sequels, has devised an excruciating new torture with “Repo! The Genetic Opera.”
